column1: New Smyrna Beach is a city in Volusia County
column2: Florida
column3: United States
column4: located on the central east coast of the state
column5: with the Atlantic Ocean to the east. Its population was estimated to be 27
column6: 843 in 2019 by the United States Census Bureau.

column1: The downtown section of the city is located on the west side of the Indian River and the Indian River Lagoon system. The Coronado Beach Bridge crosses the Intracoastal Waterway just south of Ponce de Leon Inlet
column2: connecting the mainland with the beach on the coastal barrier island.

column1: The surrounding area offers many opportunities for outdoor recreation; these include fishing
column2: sailing
column3: motorboating
column5: and hiking. Visitors participate in water sports of all kinds
column10: New Smyrna Beach was ranked number nine on the list of "best surf towns" in Surfer. It was recognized as "one of the world's top 20 surf towns" by National Geographic. in 2012. It has also been dubbed "The Shark Bite Capital of the World."

column1: The area was first settled by Europeans in 1768
column2: when Scottish physician Dr. Andrew Turnbull
column3: a friend of James Grant
column4: the governor of British East Florida
column5: established the colony of New Smyrna. Dr. Turnbull had married the daughter of a merchant from the Greek city of Smyrna (modern-day İzmir in Turkey) and named the settlement in honor of his wife's birthplace and the homeland of those in his future labor force who were Greek. No one had previously attempted to settle so many people at one time in a town in North America.Turnbull recruited about 1
column7: intending for them to grow hemp
column10: as well as to produce rum
column11: at his plantation on the northeastern Atlantic coast of Florida. The majority of the colonists came from Menorca (historically called "Minorca" in English)
column12: one of the Mediterranean Balearic Islands of Spain
column13: and were of Catalan culture and language. Around 500 or so came from Greece.

column1: Although the colony produced relatively large amounts of processed indigo in its first few years of operation
column2: it eventually collapsed after suffering major losses due to insect-borne diseases and Indian raids
column3: and growing tensions caused by mistreatment of the colonists on the part of Turnbull and his overseers. The survivors
column5: marched nearly 70 miles north on the King's Road and relocated to St. Augustine
column6: where their descendants live to this day. In 1783
column7: East and West Florida were returned to the Spanish
column8: and Turnbull abandoned his colony to retire in Charleston
column9: South Carolina.The St. Photios Greek Orthodox National Shrine on St. George Street in St. Augustine honors the Greeks among the settlers of New Smyrna; they were the first Greek Orthodox followers in North America. The historical exhibit adjoining the chapel tells the story of their plight
column11: and of their contributions to the city.Central Florida remained sparsely populated by white settlers well into the 19th century
column12: and it was frequently raided by Seminole Indians trying to protect their territory. United States troops fought against them in the Seminole Wars
column13: but they were never completely dislodged. During the Civil War in the 1860s
column14: the "Stone Wharf" of New Smyrna was shelled by Union gunboats.

column2: when New Smyrna was incorporated
column3: it had a population of 150. In 1892
column4: Henry Flagler provided service to the town via his Florida East Coast Railway. This led to a rapid increase in the area's population. Its economy grew as tourism was added to its citrus and commercial fishing industries.

column2: the city and its river islands were popular sites for moonshine stills and hideouts for rum runners
column3: who came from the Bahamas through Mosquito Inlet
column4: now Ponce de León Inlet. "New Smyrna" became "New Smyrna Beach" in 1947
column5: when the city annexed the seaside community of Coronado Beach. Today
column6: it is a resort town of over 20

column1: See also: New Smyrna Beach Historic District
New Smyrna Beach's motto is cygnus inter anates
column2: which is Latin for "a swan among ducks." The city is located in the so-called "Fun Coast" region of the state of Florida
column3: a regional term created by the Daytona Beach/Halifax area Chamber of Commerce. This coincides with the local area code
column5: which spells FUN on touchtone phones. According to the United States Census Bureau
column6: it has a total area of 37.8 square miles (98.0 km2); 34.6 square miles (89.7 km2) of it are land
column7: and 0.31 square miles (0.8 km2) of it (8.46%) is covered by water. It is bordered by the city of Port Orange to the northwest
column8: unincorporated Volusia County to the north
column9: the census-designated place of Samsula-Spruce Creek to the west
column10: and the cities of Edgewater and Bethune Beach and the Canaveral National Seashore to the south. Bounded on the east by the Atlantic Ocean
column11: New Smyrna Beach is on the Indian River. The city is connected to other parts of the state by Interstate 95

column1: Like the rest of Florida north of Lake Okeechobee
column2: New Smyrna Beach has a humid subtropical (Köppen Cfa) climate characterized by hot
column3: humid summers and mild
column4: mostly dry winters. The rainy season lasts from May until October
column6: from November to April. New Smyrna averages only about four frosts per year
column7: and many species of subtropical plants and palms are grown in the area. The city has recorded snowfall only three times in its 250-year history. The summers are long and hot
column8: with frequent severe thunderstorms in the afternoon
column9: as central Florida is the lightning capital of North America. Winters are pleasant with frequent sunny skies and dry weather.Weather hazards include hurricanes from June until November
column10: though direct hits are rare. Hurricane Charley exited over New Smyrna Beach on August 13
column12: after crossing the state in a northeastern direction from its initial landfall in Punta Gorda. The storm caused extensive damage to the beachside portion of the city and toppled many historic oak trees in the downtown area and along historic Flagler Avenue.

column1: According to the International Shark Attack File maintained by the University of Florida
column3: Volusia County had more confirmed shark bites than any other region in the world. Experts from the university have referred to the county as having the "dubious distinction as the world's shark-bite capital". The trend continued in 2008
column4: when the town broke its own record
column5: with 24 shark bites. An Orlando Sentinel photographer shot a picture of a four-foot spinner shark jumping over a surfer
